attachments.title: Homepage - Revenue Collective
attachments.text: Revenue Collective is a rare chance to find invaluable support from those in similar professional circumstances who want to see their peers succeed.

text: Kai, I know someone who’s working at Yoast who does wonders with WP SiteSpeed. Is this the type of person you’re looking for?

elements.text: Kai, I know someone who’s working at Yoast who does wonders with WP SiteSpeed. Is this the type of person you’re looking for?

text:
I’m curious to know how you update old content? How do you pick what to update? What do you do to the piece?

Here’s what we do.

*Finding content to update*

We first start with pieces ranking ~5-10, or if it used to ranking #1. Here’s what we’ll do:

• Some rewrites
• Check to see if it matches search intent
• Use MarketMuse to find gaps compared to the competition
• Make it more digestible with a table of contents and FAQs
• Fix any SEO issues
• Improve formatting
• Add internal + external links
• Update stats to be more relevant/recent
• Add custom images and video
Then we’ll move onto pieces ranking 10+. There’s usually too many of these to count, so here’s how we prioritize, in order:

1. Commercial intent - if those readers are more likely to buy, prioritize
2. Similar for any middle of the funnel content
3. Highest volume + decent relevance
4. Everything else (so maybe there's some you don't waste time on because the volume and/or relevance don't really warrant the cost or resources)
As far as how we update this content, these pieces usually need substantial rewrites (like 50-100% rewritten). Then we do all of the optimizations I mentioned above. :)

If our articles are ranking in positions ~1-3, we usually don’t touch it too much, other than basic updates, fixing any issues that pop up, or updating dates.

Who’s next? I’d love to hear some ideas!:popcorn:

Here’s what we do.
Finding content to update
We first start with pieces ranking ~5-10, or if it used to ranking #1. Here’s what we’ll do:
Some rewrites
Check to see if it matches search intent
Use MarketMuse to find gaps compared to the competition
Make it more digestible with a table of contents and FAQs
Fix any SEO issues
Improve formatting
Add internal + external links

Then we’ll move onto pieces ranking 10+. There’s usually too many of these to count, so here’s how we prioritize, in order:
Commercial intent - if those readers are more likely to buy, prioritize
Similar for any middle of the funnel content
Highest volume + decent relevance
Everything else (so maybe there's some you don't waste time on because the volume and/or relevance don't really warrant the cost or resources)

As far as how we update this content, these pieces usually need substantial rewrites (like 50-100% rewritten). Then we do all of the optimizations I mentioned above. :)

If our articles are ranking in positions ~1-3, we usually don’t touch it too much, other than basic updates, fixing any issues that pop up, or updating dates.

Who’s next? I’d love to hear some ideas!

text: Hello! Not all of our members are guys. In an effort to be more conscious of the language we use to address each other, why not try “Hey, folks,” or “Hey everyone” instead?
SEO articles should be 2,000+ words long. :+1: or :-1:?

elements.text: SEO articles should be 2,000+ words long.
or

text: SEO articles should be satisfying searchers' intent regardless of word count.

elements.text: SEO articles should be satisfying searchers' intent regardless of word count.

text: No

elements.text: No

text: <@U021QMNMQ68> is 100000% correct. Search intent > everything

elements.text: is 100000% correct. Search intent > everything

text:
Content length matters in today's environment, even if intent was addressed.

There's no content length that applies to every topic.

The best way to determine a rough target length for a topic is to get the average length of the top 10-20 pages currently ranking for the topic/keyword.

If the serp has fractured intent, only average together those pages that share the same content type / intent as the new article you're creating.

text: It really depends. We use Clearscope and in Clearscope, it tells you the amount of words for the articles that rank for that keyword. We strive to match if not beat that word count.

text: If you follow Backlinko's research, then yes it matters. But that's not all - as the rest of them said, search intent is paramount to ranking an article as well.

text:
i wouldn’t consider <@U01SMSTUWKY>’s  and Clearscopes method of target length to be the ideal way. it’s a false association. just because the top performers are a certain length doesn’t mean that it matters that much. it could be that the top site is 20 years old and has lots of authority, or they address intent really well, or its really popular and has a lot of backlinks

there are top performers that are 500 words long or less but have huge traffic because of how much value it has, and posts that are 3000 words long that are on page 10

i would argue that the article should be as long as it needs to be to provide value and answer search intent without resorting to fluff

text:
Honestly, and I've been working on this a TON over the last few weeks, I *wouldn't* average the top 10-20 results UNLESS they match the search intent.

So of those results, which ones actually match the intent and which are being surfaced because Google is looking to fill in the gaps?

wouldn't

average the top 10-20 results UNLESS they match the search intent.

So of those results, which ones actually match the intent and which are being surfaced because Google is looking to fill in the gaps?

text: ^ agree with Brendan here as well. There's a facsimile of this where you like "could" categorize the multiple intents on the SERP and average that? But even then, for topics without good content coverage the SERPs can look messy. What looks like multiple intents is actually one clear intent, but there's no great (and decently optimized) content that Google can serve up, so it serves up stuff that's semantically related and authoritative

text:
You guys are stuck on pleasing the intent gods and missing the goal of ranking and earning as quickly as possible.

You need a starting point for length anyway, so it would be logical to start with an average of the top ranking pages and going from there.

What happens if you only write for intent and see no traction at all? You're going to have to adjust the article anyway. So, why not start out with an educated guess (aka length average)?

There have been case studies that have shown that adjusting content length has directly improved rankings. I, too, have seen this on my own properties.

I'm sure you can say that an article is simply matching the intent better after the length is adjusted. But... that is still tied to content length any way you look at it.

Do as you will... but this approach gets my new content ranked in the top 20 (with no links) time and time again.

text: Hello! Not all of our members are guys. In an effort to be more conscious of the language we use to address each other, why not try “Hey, folks,” or “Hey everyone” instead?

<@U01SMSTUWKY> I don't think we're saying "length isn't important" so much as we're saying "intent comes first, then layer in relevant length information." There's a ton of optimization to do beyond just intent — but if intent is missing it becomes much much much harder to rank.

Most of our top-ranking content is over 2k words. One of our best performers is 6k words. I think length is relevant most of the time, and the reaction you're seeing here is a response to the general idea that length = good = rankings, which I would dispute as being always true.

In other words, I think we mostly agree!

In other words, I think we mostly agree!

text: Anyone got any tips on how to rank for ‘where’ keywords? For once, Google doesn’t have the answers! For example, where to buy ball point pens.

elements.text: Anyone got any tips on how to rank for ‘where’ keywords? For once, Google doesn’t have the answers! For example, where to buy ball point pens.

text: The idea of “skyscraper content” really ended up driving some confusion, to be honest. I find a lot of writers use length as a hammer looking for a nail, approaching any content problem and assuming length is the solution. It often isn’t. Angle is just as, if not more, important, for instance. When you have length top of mine, it’s too easy to assume intent is already fulfilled and that you just need more words. (That said, length is definitely still a useful tool; it just shouldn’t be the default solution, even if it’s often the best solution).

text:
my suggest is do a search of "where [your keyword]" in Google and see what comes up then build a page around that.

For example, "where to buy ball point pens" shows up Google Local Results and then mainly ecommerce pages. This means to rank as high as possible, create business pages (if that fits your business) or have ecommerce pages with ball point pens.

text:
If you’re saying that an article needs to be 2,000+ words in order to rank, *that’s absolutely incorrect*. At MarketMuse we have a massive data warehouse on content quality, word count, etc. so I can tell you that you’re barking up the wrong tree.

Can word count be useful? Yes. The average word count of the top competitors provides an indication of what’s required to adequately cover the subject.

But that doesn’t mean more words equals better content. Instead of looking at word count, look at information density. How broad and deep is your coverage vs. word count?

The real sign of expertise is being concise in your explanation. Imagine two articles that convey the same amount of information and the only difference is word count; one uses 1,000 words and the other 3,000. The shorter one wins.

MarketMuse applies a numerical value (Content Score) to each piece of content as a representation of its comprehensiveness. That combined with word count is what you really should be looking at.

Word count by itself isn’t helpful. As <@UJ2N9A3GT> points out, the whole “skyscraper content” thing is probably responsible for the misdirected belief.

text:
My marketable content refresh service includes examining posts that rank above and finding out what it's doing better.

Having a checklist is one thing - but what if your competitors are doing something that's not on your list?
